Julius E. Bernstein (1920-2010) was an American soldier who served in the United States Army during World War II. He is best known for his role in the liberation of Landsberg concentration camp in April 1945. Early Life and Military Service

Bernstein was born on October 12, 1920, in New York City. He enlisted in the United States Army in 1942, shortly after the American entry into World War II. After completing basic training, Bernstein was assigned to the 3rd Infantry Division, which was deployed to Europe in 1944. Liberation of Landsberg Concentration Camp

On April 27, 1945, Bernstein's unit, the 3rd Infantry Division, liberated Landsberg concentration camp in southern Germany. Bernstein was among the first American soldiers to enter the camp, where he witnessed the atrocities committed by the Nazi regime. The liberation of Landsberg was a significant event in the final stages of World War II, and Bernstein's role in it earned him a Bronze Star Medal. Post-War Life
